longDescription: The Hazel tree (Corylus avellana) was revered in Celtic tradition as the tree of wisdom, poetry, and divination. According to Irish mythology, nine hazel trees grew around the Well of Wisdom, dropping their nuts into the water where they were eaten by the Salmon of Knowledge. The consumption of hazelnuts was believed to grant poetic inspiration, prophecy, and mystical insight. Hazel rods were the preferred wood for divination wands and dowsing.

originPoint.name: Ireland (Well of Wisdom tradition)
originPoint.description: Central to Irish wisdom tradition. Nine hazels grow around Well of Wisdom (Connla's Well), dropping nuts eaten by Salmon of Knowledge. Hazel groves sacred to Druids, wood used for divination wands. Pan-Celtic sacred tree

etymology.derivation: From Old Irish coll (hazel). Proto-Celtic *koslos (hazel). Sacred tree of wisdom and poetry, ninth tree of Ogham alphabet. Nine hazels at Well of Wisdom produce nuts of knowledge eaten by Salmon of Knowledge

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Represents concentrated wisdom, poetic inspiration (imbas), and the sudden flash of insight. The hazelnut symbolizes wisdom in its most concentrated, portable form. The tree's connection to water (wells, streams) represents the flow of knowledge and the unconscious mind.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The hazel held a place second only to oak in Celtic tree lore. Cutting down a hazel tree was forbidden in ancient Irish law. Filid (poets) and druids carried hazel wands as symbols of their authority and wisdom. The tradition of using hazel for divining water continues today.
